entry.title: Convert PCAP files to ROSBAG
entry.content:
Hesai provides the Pandarview Software to let our users easily record and replay the point cloud data sent from Lidar. Data are recorded and stored by PCAP file format by Pandarview.

In some cases, users will need to convert the PCAP file format to ROSBAG format to make a better use of the data in ROS system. In this paper, we will go through the process of how to convert HesaiLidar PCAP files to ROSBAG:

1. Environment setup

Requirements:

  • Ubuntu PC: ROS system and HesaiLidar Ros driver installed
    for ROS driver, check our Githubsite
  • The recorded PCAP file
  • The correction file of that Lidar
    Correction file can be found from the USB drive shipped with our product or can be exported by using our PandarView software

2. Configure ROS driver

Check readme file of ROS driver and Edit the launch file:

  • Change “ pcap_file “ to the pcapfile path, eg:
    <argname="pcap_file" default="/home/hesai/Desktop/example/Pandar64.pcap"/>
  • Change “ lidar_correction_file “ to the correction file path, eg:
    <argname="lidar_correction_file" default="/home/hesai/Desktop/example/Pandar64_correction.csv"/>
  • Change “ lidar_type ” to the Lidar type, eg:
    <argname="data_type"default="Pandar64"/>

    3. Start ROSCore and record ROSBAG

  • Open terminal and start roscoreby command:
    #sudo roscore

  • Open another terminal and start rosbagrecord:
    #sudo rosbag record -b 4096 -a

4. Launch ROS driver and finish recording

  • In the “rosworkspace” folder of ROS driver, launch ROS driver by command:
    #roslaunch hesailidar hesai_lidar.launch

  • The driver will process data in the PCAP file and publish point cloud messages to ROS system. Since we’ve started the ROSBAG record command, all the messages will be recorded. After all the data from PCAP file published to ROS system, ROS driver will stop printing messages.

  • Switch to the rosbag record teminal, press “Ctrl+C” to stop the recording. The converted ROSBAG file will be stored in the path of the rosbag record terminal. Thus you got the converted ROSBAG file from the PCAP file format
entry.summary: Hesai provides the Pandarview Software to let our users easily record and replay the point cloud data sent from Lidar. Data are recorded and stored by PCAP file format by Pandarview.

entry.title: ROS Driver trouble shooting
entry.content:
Hesai provides ROS driver for our users to easily drive our Lidars in ROS system. This paper covers most common issues users may face when they use ROS driver. Arranged from the first compile step to the final application steps, reason and solution are provided for each case.

Compile issues

1. Compile error caused by compiler version not matching

Usually you will see some C++ standard operator or grammar error:

  • How to solve: upgrade compiler to G++ 7 or above

2. Compile error caused by required library missing

Usually you will see errors like libraries not found:

  • How to solve: search and install the missing libraries, in this case, the libyaml-cpp-dev library

3. Compile error caused by incorrect project path

Usually you will see errors showing some project files not found:

  • How to solve: Arrange project files to be in correct path: rosworkspce/src/(all project source files)

Launch issues

1. The “packet size mismatch” error after running launch command

This error caused by the UDP packets ROS driver received are not matching the expected size from the launch file configuration, the packets can’t be processed.

  • How to solve: check every parameter in launch file, make sure they match the Lidar configuration

2. The “Process has died” error, driver directly stops working

This may related to un-matching launch fie configuration or there is a driver process already running in system.

  • How to solve: Check every parameter in launch file, make sure they match the Lidar configuration and shutdown any other driver process or restart the system.

3. No error but no point cloud published

Reason1: System not receiving data from Lidar

  • How to solve: check if Lidar web setting page can be accessed then using wireshark software to check if system is receiving Lidar UDP packets check power and cable connection, check destination IP address setting. (If the Lidar IP address is lost, check our tutorial videos on how to find Lidar IP)

Reason2: ROS driver receiving port incorrect

  • How to solve: check the setting of the parameters in launch file. “server_ip” should be set to the Lidar IP address and “lidar_recv_port” should be set to the Lidar destination port

Reason3: ROS driver “start_angle” not within FOV

  • How to solve: Check “start_angle” parameter in launch file(default 0) and the FOV settings from “Azimuth FOV” Lidar web page, make sure “start_angle” set to within the FOV

Application issues

1. Abnormal point cloud

Correction file is used when calculate the coordinates of points. Each Lidar has its’ own correction files stores inside the Lidar. ROS driver will automatically load correction file from Lidar by command once launched. If loading failed, point coordinates might be inaccurate and point cloud published might be in a mess.

  • How to solve: Check the screen print after launching, see if “Parse Lidar correction Success!!!” printed. Make sure Lidar web page can be accessed, check and change “server_ip” field in launch file to the correct Lidar IP address.

2. Incorrect timestamp

The timestamp ROS driver published is the time from Lidar. If Lidar is not synchronized, the timestamp will be from the Lidar default time not real world time. Check Lidar synchronization status from web control home page.

  • How to solve: check the external clock source device and the connection with Lidar, make sure the time synchronization status is “Locked”. Convert timestamp to UTC time, if it’s exactly hours difference with real time, that might be because the time zone setting not matching. You can set the time zone in ROS driver to match real time on your location. Modify the “tz” parameter in main.cc to be your location time zone:
entry.summary: Hesai provides ROS driver for our users to easily drive our Lidars in ROS system. This paper covers most common issues users may face when they use ROS driver. Arranged from the first compile step to the final application steps, reason and solution are provided for each case.

entry.title: Drive multiple Lidars
entry.content:
In some applications, 2 or more Lidars are equipped, users will need to drive them together and view the point clouds in the same coordination system. Hesai’s General ROS driver project allows users to diver multiple Lidars. In this paper, we will go through the process of how to driver multiple.

Supported Lidar modules:

PandarXT PandarQT Pandar64 Pandar40P
Pandar20A Pandar20B Pandar40M

1. Clone ROS driver

Go to our Githubsite
Open the HesaiLidar_General_ROS project page, follow the instructions in readme file to download General ROS driver

2. Configure Lidar

Connect Lidars to computer and configure Lidars to have different IP address and Destination Port As an example: Set one PandarXT Lidar to IP address 192. 168. 1. 201 , Destination port to 2368
and one Pandar64 Lidar to IP address 192. 168. 1. 202 , Destination port to 2369

3. Configure ROS driver

  • Go to src/HesaiLidar_General_ROS/launchfolder
  • Make copies of the original launch file “hesai_lidar.launch”
  • Rename the copies as your preference, each launch file for one Lidar As an example: make 2 copies, name to “hesai_lidar_xt.launch” and “hesai_lidar_P64 .launch”
  • Edit launch file parameters according to the Lidar configuration, as an example:

As can see from the launch file:

  • Set correct server_ip and lidar_recv_port(server_ip and lidar_recv_port should be different for each Lidar)
  • Set correctlidar_type for each Lidar launch file
  • Set special frame_id for each Lidar launch file (frame_id should be different)
  • Set special namespace for each Lidar(namespace should be different)
  • For other parameters, set them according to each Lidar’s configuration

4. Compile ROS driver

After launch file created and edited, Compile the ROS driver: In /rosworkspace folder, open terminal and run: catkin config –install
catkin build –force-cmake

5. Launch ROS driver

After ROS driver compiled, open different terminal and launch ROS driver for each Lidar using their launch file: source install/setup.bash
roslaunch hesai_lidar xxx.launch
As an example, launch the ROS driver for Pandar64 and pandarXT- 32 in 2 terminals：

6. Start TF

About TF: TF is a ROS package that lets the user keep track of multiple coordinate frames over time. TF maintains the relationship between coordinate frames in a tree structure buffered in time, and let the user transform points, vectors, etc between any two coordinate frames at any desired point in time.

  • Start tf transformation to transform the point clouds for multiple Lidars into the same coordination system:

  • As an example: shown on the pictures, start the transformation using matric 0 0 0 0 0 0 to transform toplidar(the frame_idof Pandar64) to frontlidar(the frame_idof PandarXT)

7. Launch RVIZ

  • Start RVIZ by command in terminal: rviz
  • Add Lidar point cloud topics
  • Set the Global Options: Fixed Frame to main lidar frame_id，as an example, set to frontldiar
  • Since we started the transformation from toplidar to frontlidar, the point cloud of the 2 Lidars are shown on RVIZ

8. Trouble shooting: TF

When transformation not started correctly, you can only see one Lidar point clouds in RVIZ by setting Gloable Fixed Frame, there will be errors under the topics of other Lidar.

How to solve:

  • close RVIZ, start transformation correctly and then relaunch RIVZ

9. Trouble shooting: Timestamp

When two or more Lidars are publishing point cloud messages with different timestamp, RVIZ will not able to show them together in the same time and there will be errors under topics of other Lidars.

Howtosolve:

  • synchronize all Lidars using external clocksoure(GPS or PTP)
  • or set the timestamp_type in launch file to be “realtime”, in this way, point cloud messages will use ubuntu system time as timestamp so all Lidars can be synchronized

Hesai’s General ROS driver project allows users to diver multiple Lidars. In this paper, we will go through the process of how to driver multiple. Supported Lidar modules: PandarXT PandarQT Pandar64 Pandar40P Pandar20A Pandar20B Pandar40M

entry.title: What is Cyber Security
entry.content:
to be updated… Many people don’t use Jekyll for client projects as non-developers would traditionally have to learn HTML, Markdown and Liquid to update content. In this tutorial, we give non-developers an easy way to update Jekyll sites with CloudCannon.

What is CloudCannon?

CloudCannon is cloud content management system and hosting provider for Jekyll websites. A developer uploads a Jekyll site in the browser or by syncing with GitHub, Bitbucket or Dropbox. CloudCannon then builds the site, hosts it and provides an interface for non-technical users to update content.

Setup

To begin, we need to create a CloudCannon account and create our first site. Head over to CloudCannon and click the Get Started Free button:

Enter your details into the sign up form:

Once we’ve signed up we’re taken to our dashboard. Click Create Site:

Enter a name for the site. I’m going to use the site from the Converting a static site to Jekyll cast so I’ll call it Creative:

This creates the site and gives us options for uploading our files. If you’d like to use the same site I’m using you can download it here.

There’s a number of ways of getting your files on CloudCannon. To keep things simple we’re just going to upload a folder from our local computer. Click on the folder icon. Note: folder upload is only supported in Chrome

Navigate to your Jekyll site and click Upload:

Once the files upload, CloudCannon builds the site:

We can view the live site by clicking on the .cloudvent.net URL in the sidebar:

Editables

Next, we need to do is to define areas in our HTML which non-developers can update. These are called Editable Regions and are set by adding a class of editable to HTML elements.

Open index.html in CloudCannon and add a class of editable to the h1 and p inside <div class="header-content-inner"> so it becomes the following:

<div class="header-content-inner">
  <h1 class="editable">Your Favorite Source of Free Bootstrap Themes</h1>
  <hr>
  <p class="editable">Start Bootstrap can help you build better websites using the Bootstrap CSS framework! Just download your template and start going, no strings attached!</p>
  <a href="/about.html" class="btn btn-primary btn-xl page-scroll">Find Out More</a>
</div>

Client Access

Now the site is ready for our non-developer to update. We’ll set up Client Sharing which allows our client to update their site without having to create an account. Go to the Site Settings / Client Sharing section and set a password for your client.

Our non-developer can view their live site at your-site.cloudvent.net (or you can set up a custom domain). To update their site they just add /update to the URL and enter the password we set earlier.

The Client Workflow

Once the client logs in they see their site with colored boxes highlighting the editable regions. The client can update content directly inline by clicking on text:

By clicking Collections in the sidebar the client can manage their blog posts:

Editing posts happens in the Content Editor which is a rich text editor for Markdown. The client can also manage all the front matter data on the page using an easy-to-use editor:

Or we can use the Visual Editor to update posts:

The client can also update collection items using the same editor. In this example there’s no body content and only front matter so we’ve made the front matter editor full screen:

If we have GitHub, Bitbucket or Dropbox connected to the site, all changes the client makes are pushed back to the storage provider.

Now the client can update all the content and hasn’t had to learn HTML, Liquid or Markdown. This gives a small taste of what you can achieve on CloudCannon. Sign up free and make your Jekyll site client editable.

There’s a number of ways of getting your files on CloudCannon. To keep things simple we’re just going to upload a folder from our local computer. Click on the folder icon. Note: folder upload is only supported in Chrome

Navigate to your Jekyll site and click Upload:

Once the files upload, CloudCannon builds the site:

We can view the live site by clicking on the .cloudvent.net URL in the sidebar:

Next, we need to do is to define areas in our HTML which non-developers can update. These are called Editable Regions and are set by adding a class of editable to HTML elements.

<div class="header-content-inner">
  <h1 class="editable">Your Favorite Source of Free Bootstrap Themes</h1>
  <hr>
  <p class="editable">Start Bootstrap can help you build better websites using the Bootstrap CSS framework! Just download your template and start going, no strings attached!</p>
  <a href="/about.html" class="btn btn-primary btn-xl page-scroll">Find Out More</a>
</div>

Now the site is ready for our non-developer to update. We’ll set up Client Sharing which allows our client to update their site without having to create an account. Go to the Site Settings / Client Sharing section and set a password for your client.

Our non-developer can view their live site at your-site.cloudvent.net (or you can set up a custom domain). To update their site they just add /update to the URL and enter the password we set earlier.

The Client Workflow

Once the client logs in they see their site with colored boxes highlighting the editable regions. The client can update content directly inline by clicking on text:

By clicking Collections in the sidebar the client can manage their blog posts:

Editing posts happens in the Content Editor which is a rich text editor for Markdown. The client can also manage all the front matter data on the page using an easy-to-use editor:

Or we can use the Visual Editor to update posts:

The client can also update collection items using the same editor. In this example there’s no body content and only front matter so we’ve made the front matter editor full screen:

If we have GitHub, Bitbucket or Dropbox connected to the site, all changes the client makes are pushed back to the storage provider.

Now the client can update all the content and hasn’t had to learn HTML, Liquid or Markdown. This gives a small taste of what you can achieve on CloudCannon. Sign up free and make your Jekyll site client editable.
